titleStmt.title: Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6

summary.seg: The Syon Abbey Herbal, contained in this manuscript, is notable as the last such text to be compiled in a religious house before the Dissolution in 1539. Also remarkable is the fact that we know the identity of its author – Thomas Betson – and, unusually for even late-medieval members of the religious orders, many details of Betson's life survive. His origins remain obscure, but dialectal evidence from one his writings suggests that he may have come from near Billericay in Essex. Over the course of eight years, he studied civil and canon law at Cambridge and practised as a church lawyer. He also worked as an ordained priest, latterly for fifteen years as rector of the small parish of Wimbish. Probably in the summer of 1481, aged about 45, Betson left this post and the secular world, joining Syon Abbey as a monk. There he lived out his days until his death on 20 February 1516/17. During that time, Betson published A ryght profytable treatise, a devotional work printed by Wynkyn de Worde in 1500 (see, for example, Cambridge, University Library, Inc.5.J.1.2[3560]). He was evidently an active copyist, with four other manuscripts by or containing his hand surviving. An early printed portrait in a broadsheet produced for Syon is probably identifiable as Betson, thanks to the 'tb' monogram that accompanies the kneeling figure (see below).

Syon Abbey was a Bridgettine foundation, established by Henry V in 1415. It was first located on a site near the present Twickenham Bridge, and the foundation stone was laid by Henry on 22nd February 1415. This house proved too small and damp for habitation and new quarters were built nearby at what is now Syon House. The intended complement of these 'mixed' Bridgettine Abbeys was 60 sisters and 25 brothers, the brothers to include 13 priests – though its population never reached these numbers. Notably, all were subject to the Abbess. Syon became a centre for pilgrimage, preaching and learning, and even the publishing of printed devotional books. It was enmeshed in the divorce of Catherine of Aragon in 1533, whom it supported, and the Oath of Supremacy to Henry VIII in 1535, which it opposed. It was closed down in the Dissolution of 1539.

Betson kept the notebook shown here during his time at Syon, probably from 1500 onwards (see f. [vi] verso). It is small and almost square, only 145mm in height and 110mm in width. The skin on the wooden boards is off-white, but beneath it, particularly against the inside rear wooden board, lies what may be a typical Syon deep pink binding, now much faded. The text is on paper, with a few added sheets of parchment. The paper was sourced from at least eight different stocks. The handwriting varies from the neat to the illegible, which might reflect its compilation over many years by an increasingly elderly Betson.

The contents of the notebook are highly varied, with many short texts, the majority medical, but also religious, devotional, legal, experimental and others besides. The notebook contains an alphabetical list of the names of 700 herbal plants, many not native to Britain; they were written in Latin, French and Middle English, with some transcribed from Greek and even Arabic. Betson grouped Latin or English synonyms for these herbs under the main name, which he wrote in a larger script. To this 'Herbarium', he then added a selection of herbal remedies, a passage wholly in Latin on the use of urine for diagnosis, particularly of women's conditions, and another on herbal essences preserved in alcohol. Betson's lists of remedies were less well-organised: they appear to be in no particular order, with rubrics usually written in larger script and underlined, but often spilling into the margin. Manicules or the letters 'NB' often point out entries of apparent importance. None of these systems provided a good finding-aid for a particular illness or remedy, except for someone closely familiar with the book's contents and organisation. Given this, and its small, portable size, the likelihood is that the notebook was only ever intended for personal use.

Betson also compiled a catalogue, or 'Registrum', of Syon's books, which survives as Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 141 (see Bateson (1898) and Gillespie (2001)). It records 1,747 volumes, both manuscript and printed, and often containing multiple texts. Medical texts are especially well represented, with most of the current European medical, medical-astrological and herbal texts attested therein. In the section marked 'B', there are writings from both the medieval and classical periods, as well as translations of works originally written in Greek and Arabic. They include texts such as the Antidotarium Nicholai and the Circa instans of Platearius, both widely circulated and required reading for any trained physician.

Despite these rich resources being readily to hand, Betson seems to have used almost none of the medical, astrological or herbal books in Syon's library in compiling his own herbal. Instead he used texts that he must have acquired or borrowed from elsewhere, perhaps other religious houses. Among them was the Sinonima de nominibus herbarum of John Bray (d. 1381), physician to Edward III, perhaps in the copy preserved in London, British Library, MS Sloane 282, ff. 167v-173v (one of six surviving manuscripts). This provided the list of plants for the 'Herbarium', with some omissions (notably the poisonous mandrake; 'mandragora' in Bray).

Bray's work was also the source of of the 450 remedies that Betson's notebook contains, though there does not appear to be a correspondence between the plants cited in the 'Herbarium' and those listed in the remedies. By far the largest number are for eye problems (24), fevers and stomach problems (21 each), gout (9) and toothache (7). A number of these remedies are widely attested and were evidently common folk remedies. The phrase 'Expertum est' is sometimes written into the margins, attesting to the treatment's efficacy, but this may have been copied by Betson from his source rather than being a personal judgement.

Elsewhere, Betson used the Urina rufa and Colamentum sanguinis – two early medieval texts in wide circulation – for his section on urine flasks. For recipes for medicinal waters, Betson may have used the Breviarium Bartholomaei of John Mirfield (fl. 1390), of St Bartholomew's Hospital, London, which contains fifty such preparations.

Betson's purpose in compiling the 'Herbarium' was perhaps straightforward: to create a convenient reference book that could aid understanding of the various plant-names in the library's several herbals. The notebook makes no reference to the habitat or appearance of the plants it cites, contains no illustrations, nor instructions as to when to gather or how to store plants, or the length of their efficacy. There is no 'quid pro quo' section, a common addition to herbals that suggested possible substitutions. The resources of the library and Betson's notebook suggest that members of the Syon community possessed detailed medical, botanical and herbal knowledge, but no evidence survives of its members, male or female, putting these to practical use. An audit of the Syon Gardens by the naturalist William Turner in the late 1550s suggests that there may have been a herb garden there, though none has been located. Only 44 books from Syon's immense library are known to survive.

John Adams and Stuart Forbes
Syon Abbey Research Associates
Contact: [web@amcd.co.uk]
Website: The Syon Abbey Society

References:
John Adams, 'Syon Abbey: Its Herbal, Medical Books and Care of the Sick: Healthcare in a Mixed Mediaeval Monastery' (Syon Abbey Society [Online publication], 2015): available online
The Syon Abbey Herbal: The Last Monastic Herbal in England, c. AD 1517: From St. John's College, Cambridge, Manuscript 109 (E.6) (London: AMCD, 2015).

foliation.note: Partial foliation in pencil in the upper outer corner of the first recto of each quire from Quire 2 onward. Folio designations [i]-[iv] and [v]-[viii] were assigned to unfoliated leaves for the purposes of this electronic record when the manuscript was examined in 2023 for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project.

signatures.p: Modern quire numbers added in pencil to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.

note.p: A 16th- or 17th-century hand has made a selective table of contents for ff. 1r-43v, listing the: Casus Papales, Casus Episcopales, Decretum abbreviatum, De officio vicarii and Bonifacius De regulis Juris. The first three titles have subsequently been struck out, but a 17th-century hand has rewritten the title of the: Decretum abbreviatum.

binding.p: Dark varnished leather over wooden boards with the remains of a clasp at the centre of both boards: a triangular brass nail on the front board with the catch plate missing and a clip on the lower board. In the front cover is carved a drawing of a circular symbol with a flower resembling a hexafoil, probably with an apotropaic function; the spine features five raised bands with two modern labels printed with the shelfmark ('E' and '6'). The leather on the insides of the inner covers is white and reveals an older leather cover underneath the current one, perhaps dyed red or pink.

provenance.p: Compiled in the late 15th or early 16th century by Thomas Betson (d. 1516) Betson, Thomas, d. 1516 , librarian of Syon Abbey (1481-1516), religious author, and compiler: his name inscribed on f. 2r: Orate pro anima Thome Betson de Syon. The list of books on f. 124v likely identifies titles that were in his private possession or in Syon Abbey's library. On Betson, see Doyle (1956), 115-118; and Becket (2015).

history.provenance: The manuscript may have been incorporated into the library of Syon Abbey after Betson's death: recorded in Ker (1964), p. 308; and as 'Collectanea T. Betson (Notebook)' in the MLGB3 (mlgb3.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/mlgb/book/5354/) [accessed 15 August 2023].

provenance.p: Owned or accessed in the 16th century by Starley, (fl. 16th century) Starley, fl. 16th century , their surname inscribed on f. [ii] recto: Starley [3x] and f. 15r [1x] and f. 19r [1x].

Owned or accessed in the 16th century by Thomas Blythman, (fl. 16th century) Blytman, Thomas, fl. 16th century , his name inscribed on f. 35r: Thomas Blythman. His hand has previously not been noticed or transcribed. Perhaps Thomas Blithman, commissioner for first fruits and tenths within the Diocese of Durham, the Archdeaconry of Richmond, and Northumberland, and Westmorland (appointed in 1535) who was acquainted with Thomas Cromwell, Visitor-General of the Monasteries. As Chief Steward of Syon Abbey, a position he held from 1524, Cromwell was closely involved in the dissolution of the monastery. Perhaps Blithman acquired the manuscript directly from Cromwell. On Blithman, see Wilmott and Bryson (2013), pp. 140-142.

Purchased at an unknown time before 1624 by William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 , a lawyer, book collector, and former Johnian. Crashaw's collection numbered around 200 manuscripts and 1000 printed books.

The manuscripts and printed books owned by William Crashaw were purchased by Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 , at an unknown time before Wriothesley's death in 1624. Wriothesley had been a student-contemporary of Crashaw at St John's College and he purchased Crashaw's collection with the intention to present the volumes as a gift to the Library of St John's College. The library was still partly under construction at the time of the purchase resulting in the Wriothesley family storing Crashaw's collection and delivering it piecemeal to the College over a number of years.

After Henry Wriothesley's death in 1624 and William Crashaw's death in 1626, care of Crashaw's books and manuscripts passed to Wriothesley's son, Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 . Although Crashaw's printed books seem to have been passed to the College without incident, Thomas Wriothesley seems to have taken a particular interest in the manuscripts, adding his name typically in the form 'Tho: C. S.' for Thomas comes southamptoniensis ('Thomas, Earl of Southampton') to most of them, and apparently exhibiting such reluctance to deliver the manuscripts that the College wrote to his mother, Elizabeth Vernon Southampton, Elizabeth Vernon Wriothesley, Countess of, 1573-1655? to ask her to encourage her son to hand over the volumes.

history.acquisition: Given to St John’s College in 1635 by Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 on behalf of William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 and Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 . The initials ‘Tho. C. S.’ in ink (for Thomas Comes Southamptoniensis) are present on the outside of the upper cover. William Crashaw's bookplate recording the donation is present on the inside of the lower cover. St John's College's bookplate pasted on the inside of the front cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of St John's College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1913).

availability.p: Visitors to St John's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: St John's College: Old Library and Special Collections.

msItem.explicit: [iv] verso quia tu es vere lucis. Tendens ad uer[a]

msItem.note: Added by (?) Thomas Betson; not transcribed.

msItem.title: Untranscribed verse or note
msItem.note: Added by (?) Thomas Betson; not transcribed.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: [ii] verso Thomas manum yn
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Thomas Betson (?), perhaps referring to a chant for St Thomas Becket: "Thomas manum mittit".

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: [iv] recto Willelmus permissione diuinia
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Thomas Betson (?).

msItem.title: Liturgical songs
msItem.incipit: [v] recto -dentes que dat talem filium
msItem.explicit: [viii] verso Immo ambo iam parentes in maria sunt g[audentes]

msItem.title: Metamorphoses [excerpt]
msItem.author: Ovid
msItem.incipit: [v] recto Prona que conspectent animalia cetera terram / Deus homini sublime dedidt celumque uidere / Jussit et erectos ad sidera tollere uultus
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Note on fox grape
msItem.incipit: [v] recto Labrusca: vitis silvestris inter spineta et mutilis
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Note on (?) applause
msItem.incipit: [v] recto Complosus [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Prophecy for the year 1500
msItem.incipit: [vi] verso Anno domini 1500 peribit omnis caro per ignem
msItem.note: Added by (?) Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: [vi] verso Militat in teneris annis amor hospes amenus / Est in canicie ridiculosa venus
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: [vi] verso Stulticia est que te non finit esse senem
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Betson.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: [vi] verso Exultat leui puer gravitate senectus / Inter vtrumque manens stat iuuenile decus
msItem.note: Added by Thomas Betson; the text is followed by a note that has not been transcribed.

msItem.title: Medical recipe (?)
msItem.incipit: [vii] verso The powder for the priste is made of þe fume of j li. of pych subtillie and demi pynt of oyle burnyng in a cloute vndir a pott the mowth beyng dounward And the licour is oyle of lynsede or vernyssh
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 15th-century hand.

seg.note: These measures are the dimensions of the leaves as they are currently presented in the manuscript (the eight leaves have been bound into the manuscript in such a way that the text is vertically oriented) and do not attempt to give an estimate of the size of the original larger leaves from which these fragments were taken.

p.seg: Ruled in (?) leadpoint, frame only. Due to the fragmentary nature of the leaves, it is imposible to establish the number of lines to the page.

handNote.p: The text accompanying the music notation has been copied by a single hand in Northern Textualis.
Most of the additions to the fragmentary leaves have been copied by a cursive hand, Thomas Betson, including both secretary and anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Large plain initials in blue or red ink.
Five-line music staves drawn with red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.6, ff. 1-124

msItem.explicit: 2r Quarta regula est iusticia vult tribuere ius vnicumque qualiter hoc deb

msItem.note: Added by the same hand that added an alphabet above the prayer.

msItem.incipit: 2r ben sta chi proua / bene stat qui probat
msItem.note: Added by the same hand as the above verse.

msItem.title: Tract on multiple births
msItem.incipit: 2v Argumentatur iuris consultus per Aristotilem ff desolacione si pater vbi probat quod quinque sunt receptacula vulne mulieris
msItem.explicit: 2v et tempore celesti quedam mulier de dacia confessa quod simul peperit nouiem prout legitur ingestis Ecclesie Romane

msItem.title: Verses

msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verses
msItem.incipit: 2v Versus: Dicitur agnatus ex patris tibi in
msItem.explicit: 2v Eius filius est quod nupcie demonstr[a]nt

msItem.title: Verses
msItem.incipit: 2v Versus: Liber erat vivus sed serus morte latinus / Atque dedicios cum nece liber erat
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verses

msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verses
msItem.incipit: 2v Qui ab ancillis nostris nascuntur
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verses and notes
msItem.incipit: 2v Qui non potest bursa soluere l[...]et mihi corpore
msItem.explicit: 4v Muneribus dandis attendas quattuor ifta / Qui dans quisue petens res qui causa petendi
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Experiments for making illusions, secret and invisible writing, knife tricks, and changing the taste of food and drink
msItem.rubric: 4v De dioletica de quo tractatur ad tale signum potes facere speculum
msItem.incipit: 4v De visu et qualiter decipitur in quo vno visu apperebunt multe ymagines
msItem.explicit: 10r et primum secundum diuersum situm apperibit diuersa ymago etcaetera. Tunc procedas ante in 6o foliis ad talem signum [symbol]
msItem.note: For invisible writing, one text is encoded by replacing all its letters for their next letters in the alphabet. This method for secret writing is similar to the method in which only the vowels are replaced for their next letters in the alphabet, which is described on f. 7r. This text in question on f. 7v reads: Aliud modus cum xskobn [vrinam]: cum pulueri spargendo scribendo + Non + et notatur in secretis 7 [?] horis.
Similar tricks can be found in London, British Library, Harley MS 866, ff. 1r-7v.

msItem.title: John 13:20 in cypher
msItem.note: Amen dico vobis is written (in the lower margin) in cypher as: 1m2n d3c4 54b3s.

msItem.title: Explanation of the Ten Commandments
msItem.incipit: 10v Worship no fals goddes: ffirst pater noster aue and credo. In þis is forbodun al maner mawmatry wichecraft . Enchaunmentes. Redyng of dremys and alle mysbileue
msItem.explicit: 10v Desire not þi neiȝbouris thyng: house . londe . Beste. seruaunt . ne no þing þat is his.

msItem.explicit: 11v Mesure Temperancia: þis is a mene bitwene to moche and to litell and it stondith in takyng sufficiently þat ne dith And in refusyng vttirly þat is to moche orto litill
msItem.finalRubric: 11v Bi þese þynges shcal eche man and woman knowe god almyȝty - Betson
msItem.note: Full transcription. the first gift lacks its heading ('Faith') and definition.

msItem.title: Humility
msItem.incipit: 12r Prudencia Fortitudo Justicia Temperancia Fides Spes Caritas

msItem.title: De sex alis

msItem.title: Recipe for making light in the night

msItem.title: Recipe for driving flies from a house
Four recipes for making dyes in different colours
msItem.note: The recipes are headed: To make rede turnsall; To make blew turnsall; To make yelow turnsall; To make grene turnsall.

msItem.title: Tract on canon law

msItem.incipit: 14r [L]iber decretorum distinctus est in tres partes
msItem.explicit: 16v In prima an liceat
msItem.note: This work has been attributed to various authors, see Mirabile.

msItem.title: Theological tract
msItem.incipit: 17r Sunt multe Insule que nunquam habuerunt Regem neque legem sed viuiunt secundum racionem
msItem.explicit: 17r et ad lucrandum tocium mundum sollicitus vt [...] etcaetera

msItem.title: Line from a (?) mystery play
msItem.incipit: 20r Ad me facta pater assit deus et sua mater
msItem.note: Elsewhere, this line appears to be found only in the Coventry Corpus Christi Pageants.

msItem.title: Line from a (?) mystery play
msItem.incipit: 20r Ad me facta pater assit deus et sua mater
msItem.note: Elsewhere, this line appears to be found only in the Coventry Corpus Christi Pageants.

msItem.title: Verse mnemonic for Ember Days
msItem.incipit: 20v Crux dat lucia civis et karismata dia / Ne sis in angaria quarta sequens feria
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Dietary advice from the Regimen sanitatis Salernitanum
msItem.incipit: 20v Si tibi deficiant medici, medici tibi fiant / Hec tria mens leta labor moderata dieta
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Blessing for a fraternity
msItem.incipit: 20v Et vestram fraternitatem venerabilem dirigat iuxta vota elsior in caelis regnare et regemur universa
msItem.finalRubric: 20v Scripta Eboracensis vester ad nutum Jo. P."
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Model letter
msItem.incipit: 20v Honorande [? magister] debita recommendacione premissa cum graciarum accione
msItem.explicit: 20v Et si quid erit ad vestrem placitum per me fieri posse deo amante promptissimum ad id me fore promitto

msItem.title: Unidentified tract
msItem.textLang: Latin with a few (?) Englis hwords
msItem.incipit: 20v misas et expensas ad custos suas proprios
msItem.explicit: 20v thrisfalowid

msItem.title: Verses from Ovid, Amores
msItem.incipit: 21r Quos peciere duces animos in milite forti / Hos petit in socio bella puella
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: A Sator [Arepo] Square
msItem.note: Added by a later (16th-century) hand.

msItem.title: Legal notes from the Lex Authentica
msItem.incipit: 21v Vxores coruscant radijs maritorum c. iiij. de conulibus § si vero
msItem.explicit: 21v Imperatori deus leges subiecit lege animatam cum mittens hominibus
msItem.note: The first note identifeis the Lex Authentica as its source.

msItem.title: Tract on law
msItem.rubric: 22r De regulis iuris vt notantus ff. nono
msItem.incipit: 22r Regula [crossed out: est] que rem que est breuiter enarrat non vt ex regula ius sumarum sed ex iure quod est regula fiat per regulam breuis narratio traditur ut et Sabinus quasi coniectio est que simul cum [crossed out: est] in aliquo uiciata est perdit officium suum
msItem.explicit: 23v Inuitus nemo cogitur defendere rem de qua agitur. Cui damus accionem eidem excepcionem eidem competem multo magis quis dicet

msItem.title: Mnemonic of the dioceses in England
msItem.rubric: 23r E.ly ba.[the] carlil can[terbery] chichester lin.[colne] lundon [sic] deorham ex.eter ebo[raci] wyn[chester] wor[chester] rimond ro[chester] Salus[bury] presules habet anglia tales
msItem.note: Full transcription. A similar mnemonic survives in London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 762,, f. 95r [printed in Reliquiae antiquae, 1 (1845), pp. 287-288].

msItem.title: Note about money
msItem.incipit: 24r Qui expendit in die vnum denarius
msItem.explicit: 24r Hoc tamen excepto die quod expenditur vno

msItem.title: Two-line verse about priests
msItem.incipit: 24r Presbiteri nati non possunt esse beati / Sunt infelices quia matres sunt meretrices
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem about priests
msItem.incipit: 24r Si male viuentes me progennere [sic] parentes
msItem.explicit: 24r vel non est munda sacri baptismatis vnda

msItem.title: Note on simony
msItem.incipit: 24r Nota de symonia

msItem.title: Theological notes
msItem.incipit: 24r Omnibus hominibus vite est mors coll. j. et nullus
msItem.explicit: 24r Castitas sola cum fiducia possibilis deo animas hominum presentare de lenonibus collacio iij § sancimus

msItem.title: Calculation of the distance between the earth and the stars
msItem.rubric: 24v A terra vsque ad firmamentum sunt 54ml[...]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Casus papales episcopales et abbatiales
msItem.incipit: 25v Primus casus papalis est in illo qui percutit enormiter clericum
msItem.explicit: 28r Quintus est si est de consuetudine alicuius dyocesis quod certa crimina ad episcopum remittantur
28r Expliciunt casus episcopales
msItem.note: This copy is missing the section on abbots.

msItem.title: Item quaecunque (Constitution)
msItem.rubric: 27v Fredericus Imperator Romanorum de libertatibus ecclesie in statute ad decus in §
msItem.incipit: 27v Item quecumque comitas vel persona per animum in excommunicacione propter libertatem ecclesie perstiteruit ipse
msItem.explicit: 27v si qui clericis vel persone ecclesiasticis iusticiam denegare presumpserint tercio requisiti suam iurisdictionem amittant etcaetera - In alia statuta habita

msItem.title: Theological note
msItem.incipit: 27v Dignum namque in eis est estima minus vt cum cum bona facientes nostram laudem et prteccionem omnes mereantur eos quorum mundus illuminatur ad obediendum deo
msItem.explicit: 27v et nota plus i.

msItem.title: Epitaph of the Duke of Buckingham
msItem.incipit: 28v Materiam flendi tullit heu mars atque dolendi
msItem.explicit: 28v Et greget [...] hunc sine fine ducem

msItem.title: Epitaphium Terentii
msItem.incipit: 28v Natus in excelsis tectis carthaginis alte
msItem.explicit: 28v sic puto cautus erit

msItem.title: Epitaph of Llywelyn ap Iorwerth
msItem.incipit: 28v Hic iacet anglorum tortor tutor venedorum
msItem.explicit: 28v fforma futurorum . laus dux . lex lux populorum

msItem.title: Epitaph of Llywelyn ap Iorwerth
msItem.rubric: 28v Responsio anglici in contemptu versuum preceden.
msItem.incipit: 28v Hic iacet errorum princeps et predo viuorum
msItem.explicit: 28v ffex troianorum stirps mendax causa malorum

msItem.title: Medical verses
msItem.incipit: 29r Scabida facta pecus totum corrumpit [...] / Regna regunt vulne clamitat tota gens et simul ve
msItem.explicit: 29r Inficiuntur oves velut ex vna scabiosa / Sic probus a reprobo fit viciosus g[...]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Note on the practice of medicine
msItem.incipit: 29v Habet in omne artificium in suo [...] de transactis ad que sequuntur experimentorum fidem sicut agricola sit pastor sic nauta
msItem.explicit: 29v quibus omnibus stabilis et curiose omnis per elementorum motus temporum altaciones [sic] solis et lune atque stellarum cursus experimenta fidem faciunt

msItem.title: Method of determining a woman's pregnancy
msItem.incipit: 29v Habita namque suspicione pregnantis cum id experimento discernendum
msItem.explicit: 29v Alio quoque modo acceptum [...] inter dignitos lac pregnantis si spissum viscosum que [...] masculi signum varum et liquidum femine

msItem.title: Medical note for women
msItem.incipit: 29v Nota quando matrix ascendit mulier ponit super [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Six aspects of Urine

msItem.explicit: 30r per odorem per circulum per ypostasim per consistencia

msItem.title: Tract on red urine

msItem.title: Tract on Women's Urine

msItem.explicit: 30r Pulvis silicis nigre bene prouocat vrinam vt expertum a quampluribus

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating migraine

msItem.explicit: 30v iacendo super cepe per duas horas vel per unam ad minus.

msItem.title: Definition of Cosmagraphia
msItem.incipit: 30r Cosmagraphia est mappa mundi
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: 30r Bulgarus os auri martinus copia legum / Est hugo mens legis subtilior illius / Hoc opus magnum sui accurso non videlicet agnum
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Theological notes on husbands and wives
msItem.incipit: 30v [...] Nota inter fidem et iuramentum non facit deus differentiam
msItem.explicit: 31v non plures si plures accedant et leuant omnes sunt spirituales to tio .c. si.

msItem.title: Tract on the office of vicar
Tract on Wisdom based on Ecclesiastes
Recipes to give a coin a gold colour
msItem.incipit: 35 Vt denarius apperebit oreus
msItem.explicit: 35 et durabit per annum et amplius

msItem.title: Recipe to kill rats
msItem.textLang: English recipe with a Latin heading
msItem.incipit: 35v Take a procioun of fressh grece and a porcioun of grotes of otemele
msItem.explicit: 36r and sett fere water and a bundel of hey or straw and in the morow thou shal fynd hem dede probatum est

msItem.title: Recipe to make a corrosive
msItem.rubric: 36r Draw a corosif of j. litre of vitriole and j. litre and s. of sal peter
msItem.explicit: 36r and it wole bole to gidere and whan it is lest boilyng it is sowditt and fast knyt togider

msItem.title: Recipe to make gilding water
msItem.incipit: 36r Draw a corosif of a pounde of virtriole
msItem.explicit: 36r And thus þou may gilt siluer coper and glas pro duracione magna

msItem.title: Instructions for planting and grafting
msItem.incipit: 36v Take an ympe of two yeris growyng with oon knot and wryth hit and take awey þe berk þerof and þe knot and take a graf as gret as ye ympe is and graf þem to gider and þei shal sone prene
msItem.explicit: 38r ffor to haue grapis assone ripe as peris or cheries take a ȝong vyne þat stonth be a ȝong plum tre or chery tre and at þe sesoun of vynes cuttyng bore a hole of grenes of þe vyne þe tre and put þe vyne þorug and stop it well in euery syd with clay þat no water enter it and whan it is growen with þe tre kut þe vyn tow and þe rote saf by þe tree

msItem.title: Notes on confession
msItem.incipit: 38v Sit simplex humilis confessio pura fidelis
msItem.explicit: 38v et ne desperet pre multitudine peccatorum extra de petro magdalenam etcaetera

msItem.title: Vado mori poem
msItem.rubric: 39v Nota istos versus pro optimis mors
msItem.incipit: 39v Equa lege capit magnos atque pusillos
msItem.explicit: 39v Qui subito rapuit penituisse mori / Omne quod est nichil est preter amare deum

msItem.title: Latin epigrams from Hermaphroditus (1425)
msItem.author: Antonio Beccadelli
msItem.incipit: 40r Si qua tuus queritur parcissime lelphe caballus
msItem.explicit: 40v Quo ruitis modo vos pellis et ossa manent
msItem.finalRubric: 40v Explicit vna epistola vnius Italici ad alterum [...]

msItem.title: Collection of verses
msItem.incipit: 40v Hec abathia ruit opus est nimium michi triste / Intus ex extra pluit terribilis est locus iste
msItem.explicit: 40v Stabilis in ecclesiae, humilis in congregacione et sagax in diuinorum administracione

msItem.title: Liber V, Titulus XII from the Liber Sextus Decretalium
msItem.author: Pope Boniface VIII
msItem.rubric: 41r De regulis iuris Bonefacii in vje
msItem.incipit: 41r Beneficium eclesiasticum non potest licite sine institucione obtineri
msItem.explicit: 43v Certum est quod is committit in legem qui legis verba complectens contra legis nititur voluntatem
msItem.finalRubric: 43v Explicit bonefacius de Regulis iuris in sui 6to

msItem.title: Canon law selections
msItem.incipit: 43v Quod alicui licet non licet nomini alicuo non
msItem.explicit: 45r Diaconissam in sancta ecclesia non ordinari prcecipimus que minor sit xl. annorum aut ad 2as venerit nupcias. Presbyterum minorem xxxv. annus fieri non permittimus sed neque diaconum aut subdiaconum minorem xxv. annis nec lectorem minorem xviij annis. Item episcopum minorem xxxv annis ordinari prohibeamur [...]

msItem.title: Canon laws attributed to John Chrysostom
msItem.rubric: 45v Johannes Crisostomus de Regulis iuris [? antiqui]
msItem.incipit: 45v Omnis res per quascumque causas nascitur per eas dissoluitur
msItem.explicit: 46r Propter actus virtuosos dantur dignitates
msItem.note: The text features another section with the header: Idem in libro de penitencia.

msItem.title: Excerpts from Ecclesiasticus
msItem.incipit: 46v Melius est a sapiente corripi quam stultorum adulacionibus decipi
msItem.explicit: 46v Melior est pauper sanus et fortis viribus quam dives imbecillis et malicia flagellatus

msItem.title: Excerpts from classical works (Sententiae)
msItem.incipit: 46v Dum furor in cursu est currenti cede furori
msItem.explicit: 47r Omitte excusacionem nemo peccat invitus

msItem.title: Excerps from Ecclesiastes
msItem.incipit: 47r Laborant multi in sapiencia doctrina
msItem.explicit: 47r Deum time et mandata eius obserua: hoc est omnis homo. Cuncta que fiunt se sole adducet deus in iudiciumpro omni errato sive bonum siue malum

msItem.title: Extract from the Codex Justiniani
msItem.incipit: 47v Si quemquam vel in hac urbe regia vel in ceteris provincijs que toto orbe diffuse sunt ad episcopatus gradum prouehi deo auctore contigerit
msItem.explicit: 47v vt eos quos par facinus coinquinat et equat utrosque similis pena comitetur

msItem.title: Proverbia Senecae and other Sententiae
msItem.incipit: 48r Discute quod audias et proba quod credas / Ab alio expectes alteri quod feceris
msItem.explicit: 48r Mora omnis odiosa est sed facit sapienciam

msItem.title: Memorandum about a tamed lark
msItem.incipit: 48v recolo quemdam satis nuper diebus per domasse alaudam si ac domitam catasta [=cage] claustrasse cum quandoque [?] parum [?] licencius volet: instinctu cum mori motus sui ad solitam edem revolans mox adeo dulciter modulatur ac si suo instilasse guttis [?] melipepo
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Definition of the word "arbustum"
msItem.incipit: 48v Arbustum est quedam species [?] peponis [...]

msItem.title: Proverbia Senecae and other Sententiae
msItem.incipit: 48v Quis est pauper qui sibi videtur diues
msItem.explicit: 48v Chilo tercius: Amicos dilige tanquam forte habiturus inimicos

msItem.title: Summary of the Decretals of Gregory IX
msItem.rubric: 49r Istud prothocolium de libris 5ti clementis et decretalium in summis eorum
msItem.incipit: 49r Licet constitucio generalis non reuocat constituciones vel consuetidines locales nisi in ea caveatur expresse
msItem.explicit: 67r Indignum exemplum patet de symonia capitulo ex diligenti

msItem.title: Treatise on planting and grafting trees
msItem.incipit: 67v In equinoxijs vbique terrarum terra magis dispo
msItem.explicit: 70r et sepeliatur in terra pingus cum funo subtractis ligaturis ad profunditatem competem

msItem.textLang: Latin, Middle French, and Middle English
msItem.incipit: 70r Alleluya Panis cuculi Wodesour Chemerek Steuenwort
msItem.explicit: 83r Tintensa impetigo vt supra

listBibl.bibl: Adams and Forbes (2015), p. 86 [discussion], pp. 87-216 [full transcription].

msItem.title: Miscellaneous recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes medical recipes for ailments in humans, but also an equestrian medical recipe for a horse with saddle or harnass galls ("ffor an hors is gallid"), and recipes for washing ("for a mole in a lynen cloth" and "ffor cloth þat is stemed").

msItem.title: Latin tract of uroscopic signs
msItem.incipit: 84r [V]rina Rufa significat salutem et bonam dispositionem corporis humani
msItem.explicit: 86r Et aliquando sedimen est nigrum et tunc nisi fuerit per talem vrinam expulsio materie venenose signum est mortis

listBibl.bibl: Adams and Forbes (2015), pp. 223-224 [discussion], pp. 225-229 [full transcription].

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings

msItem.title: De planetis et eorum virtute
msItem.author: (?) Walter Burley
msItem.incipit: 86v [S]ciendum est igitur signis nascatur in aliqua hora diei in qua dominatur quis septem planetarum pronior erit ad bonum siue malum secundum influenciam illius planete in qua natus est
msItem.explicit: 88v si vero sub maliuola constellatione natus fuerit a malo ad quod dispositus est seipsum declinet
msItem.note: See Gensler (2004), for an edition of the text from Lambeth, Palace Library, MS 70 and London, Lambeth Palace Library, MS 74. According to Gensler, the text has only been identified in these two manuscripts among texts of the 14th-century philosopher Walter Burley [Burleigh] (c. 1275-1344). However, more copies appear to exist: the same treatise also appears to survive in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 391 and Oxford, Bodleian Library, 4º D 21 Jur..

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings

msItem.title: Psalm 37:22 and 1 Peter 1:25)
msItem.incipit: 88v Ne derelinquas - Verbum domini manet in eternum
msItem.note: Full transcription; added to the lower margin (and written upside down) by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Ecclesiasticus 10:2
msItem.incipit: 89r habesque candide lector = Sicut Judex populi ita et ministri eius et qualis rector ciuitatis talis et inhabitantes
msItem.note: Full transcription; added to the lower margin (and written upside down) by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Three recipes for making soap
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with a Latin header
msItem.incipit: 89v ffor to make white sope: Take ij. busshel of bone asshis or of wode and sift hem cleen ina faire flour
msItem.explicit: 90r boile forth til it be white and not grecye nor smelling of tallowe þen cast it in amoldis and dresse it as þou wole haue it
msItem.note: The recipes are titled ffor to make white sope, ffor toe make blak sope, and de albo sapone.

msItem.title: Recipe for making Oil of Tartar
msItem.incipit: 90r Recipe: j li. of tarar made of lies of wyn put hem in an erden pot wel auelid and fire him strongly vntill he tunid into salt þan lete him be sette in a moist place til he relent into oyle
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for all ailments
msItem.rubric: 90r ffor alle maner of euels in a mannys body
msItem.incipit: 90r Recipe scabiose pimpernell turmentil and detaign wormode and fumiter golde make a water of all þiese and drink it
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Treatise on the medicinal virtues of herbs
msItem.incipit: 90v mugworte moderworte id. ypocras seith it is hote and dry in the thirde degree this helpith to conceyue childe and clensith the womb and makith a woman to haue her flouris and destroyeth the emerodis þat growen in the fundament
msItem.explicit: 94r Also stampe it with buttur and seth iti n white wyn and it shal make him þat is stokun in the breest forto delyuer glet and filth

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings

msItem.title: Miscellaneous culinary and household recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes (a) culinary recipes to make vinegar, prevent beer from going sour, to treat discoloured white wine, to preserve bread, to change vinegar into wine, to preserve roses and fruits; (b) recipes against vermin, including recipes to catch moles and snakes, and to rid malt of worms; and (c) recipes for inks, including recipes for writing on a knife, for writing gilded letters, and for writing letters that can be read during the night but not during the day.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin headings

listBibl.bibl: Adams and Forbes (2015), pp. pp. 249-264 [full transcription].

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 101v Qui tetigerit picem et qui in misericordia
msItem.note: Full transcription; added to the lower margin (and written upside down) by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for medicinal waters
msItem.incipit: 102r Aqua Eufrasie: Aqua Eufrasie sic fit: extrahatur aqua de folii eufrasie singularia et specialia sunt
msItem.explicit: 109v fit de Oleo Tartari et Litargio et Camphora et Cerusa: ana cum succo vitis idest Bironie

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for medicinal oils
msItem.rubric: 109v Incipit de Oleis - Oleum de sinapio valet in paralisi et contra emigraneum ex frigida causa
msItem.incipit: 109v Oleum Rosarum sic fit: Recipe flores Rosarum viridium et repleatur fiola de floribus
msItem.explicit: 111r Oleum de sinapio valet in paralisi et contra emigraneum ex frigida causa Explicit

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for medicinal unguents, plasters, potions, sirups, suppositiroes, and concoctions
msItem.incipit: 111r Vnguentum contra Guttam: Recipe vnum canem antiquum et pinguem valde in Autumpno inter festum assumpcionis et nativitatis Beate Marie corea eum et tolle intestina cum capite et pedibus sed non apponas aliquid aquam ad illum quando extrahis intestina
msItem.explicit: 115r Valet multum antiquis hominibus quia habent confortari viscera
msItem.note: The collection features a number of subdivisions, including a collection of recipes for medical sirups (Compositiones Siruporum) on ff. 113v-114r; a collection of suppositories for an enema (Suppositoria et Pessaria Compositiones clisterarum) on ff. 114r-114v); and medical concoctions (Compositiones Confectionum) on ff. 114v-115r.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 114v Recipe 1 partem salis petri et aliam calcis vini \lyme/ et molle super marmoreum et ponatur vnum super [? octo lane] et [? venerit] et erit bonum et [? diminuendo] est calidum pon[a]tur in vergious
msItem.note: Added in the lower margin by a different hand.

listBibl.bibl: Fully transcribed by Adams and Forbes (2015), p. 298 but with a few errors (sulphuri vive for calcis vini [omittting the English gloss lyme]; potatur urina for ponatur vnum) and leaving the last seven words untranscribed. Where Adams and Forbes transcribe lune the text may read lane, referring to lana succida (alo spelled lane succide): unwashed sheep's wool that was used for the application of medical oils and ointments.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for mygraine and pain.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes (purgatives and laxatives)
Verse on the astrological times for bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 116v Est Aries minuendo bonus sic libra sagitta / Sic et aquarius est nec non pisces que taurus
msItem.note: Transcribed in Adams and Forbes (2015), p. 302 but with an errorenous transcription of muniendo for minuendo and leaving the words que taurus untranscribed. The transcription also suggests that the two verse lines are continued with a list of herbs: Politricum, Adiantos, Capillus Veneris, Centauria, Mirabolani. However, this list is a continuation of the medical recipe on f. 116r.

msItem.title: Four medical recipes
msItem.note: The purposes of the medical recipes are Pro colica passione, for migraine, to make hair grow, and Pro colica.

msItem.title: Almanac with dietary advice and prognostics for each month of the year
msItem.incipit: 116v Mense Octobri Lac caprinum et muscum bibe propter sanguinem dulciendum et pulmonem curandum
msItem.explicit: 117r Si tonitrum sonuerit habundanciam frugum et et ocasionem potentum significat

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Not transcribed in Adams and Forbes (2015).

msItem.title: Extracts from chronicles
msItem.incipit: 117v Iubal pater canencium in cithara et organo inuentor fuit musice consonanciarum
msItem.explicit: 119v hoc tempore nati sunt pueros vnus quadrupes et aliter duos vertices habens

msItem.title: Reckoning of years from the Creation until the birth of Christ and for the Six Ages of the World
msItem.incipit: 119v Anno ab origine mundi vsque ad incarnacionem vM C lxxxxix ann.
msItem.explicit: 119v a Christo vsque adventum Christi ad judicium
msItem.note: The tract only includes five of the Six Ages of the World, excluding the fifth age from the Babylonian exile to the birth of Christ.

msItem.title: Collection of medical and culinary recipes
msItem.note: The collection features a single culinary recipe ffor mylk of almondes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Added in the (?) early 16th century; not transcribed by Adams and Forbes (2015).

msItem.title: Epistola 41
msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.incipit: 123v Quid melius animo geramus et ore promamus et calamo explanemus exprimamus quam deo gracias. Hec nec dici breuius nec audiri le[t]ius nec intelligi grandius nec agi fructuosius potest
msItem.note: Full transcription.

listBibl.bibl: Adams and Forbes (2015), pp. 305-306 [transcription of the recipes on f. 124r only].

msItem.title: Medical advice
msItem.incipit: 124r Ieiuna, vigila, modicum bibe, sepe labore / Te calidum serva, si vis expellare flegma

msItem.title: List of books
msItem.incipit: 124v Holcot super sapienciam / Distinciones boroston / Sermones Magdalene / Water[s]on Sermones - Cum biblia
msItem.note: Full transcription; the list refers to Robert Holcot's Super sapientiam Salomonis; Simon Boraston's Distinciones theologiae; Sermones domnicales seu Sermones Mawdelyen of John Felton (fl. 1430); and an unidentified sermon collection.

msItem.title: Epistulae [excerpt]
msItem.author: Sidonius Apollinaris
msItem.incipit: 124v Porro autem barbarismus est morum sermo iocundus et animus afflictus

support.material: Paper quires with outer and inner leaves of parchment.

Paper, folded in octavo with various watermarks in the upper left margin of the folio, including a bull's head and grapes. See Adams and Forbes (2015), pp. 75-76 for a more detailed discussion of the eight watermarks they identify.

p.seg: ff. 1r-40v have been ruled in ink. Mainly single columns, except for ff. 10v-11r which have two columns. 27-34 lines to the page, written below top line.
ff. 41r-124v have been ruled in hardpoint, frames only. Mainly single columns, except for ff. 70r-83r which have two columns. 29-34 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Largely copied by in the cursive hand of Thomas Betson, featuring both secretary and anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Interlaced decorative motifs in brown ink added to the lower margin of f. 29v, the inner margin of f. 34v, and the originally empty page of f. 35r.
Drawing of fish in brown ink added to the upper and lower margin of f. 34v and the originally empty page of f. 35r.
Manicules in brown ink added to the margins of ff. 61v, 64v, and 65r.
Drawings of eyes in brown ink both in the upper margin of and inside the text on f. 96v, illustrating two medical recipe for ailments in the eyes.
A drawing of a medical instrument in brown ink in the inner margin of f. 112v.
Cadels in brown ink occasionally on the ascenders of letters on the top lines and descenders on letters of the bottom lines.
Two large circula star diagrams in brown ink on ff. 24v-25r.
Two large plain initials in red ink on f. 2r.
One large (7-line) initial in red ink in a frame of penwork in brown ink on f. 1r.
Display capitals on f. 1r highlighted in red.
Paraphs in red ink on ff. 10v-12r.
Underlining in red ink on ff. 10v-12r.

origin.origDate: Copied by Thomas Betson during his time at Syon Abbey between 1481 and 1516.
origin.origPlace: The Monastery of St Saviour and St Bridget of Syon, also known as Syon Abbey, in Twickenham, London.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
